title: A Case of Rhabdomyolysis Induced by Intense Physical Activity
clinical_history: A 32-year-old male, who is an amateur marathon runner, presented to the clinic with a 2-day history of severe muscle pain and weakness. He reported completing a particularly grueling training session 2 days prior, which included an intense 10-mile run uphill. He noted that he did not adequately hydrate during the run and consumed only minimal fluids post-exercise. Following the run, he experienced increasing pain and stiffness in his lower extremities, which progressed to include his upper body. He also reported dark-colored urine and decreased urine output.

nprs.affected_area: Bilateral lower extremity muscle pain, particularly in the quadriceps, hamstrings, and gastrocnemius muscles

aggrevating_factors: Movement, palpation, and stretching of affected muscles
picture: A 24-hour urine output chart showing decreased output, and laboratory results indicating elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels and myoglobinuria
past_history: No significant past medical history, but he has had occasional episodes of muscle cramping during intense exercise
medical_history: Generally healthy, but has been taking ibuprofen for muscle soreness in the past
personal_history: Married with two children, works as a software engineer, and has a history of regular physical activity
imaging: None to date, but laboratory results show elevated CK levels (>10,000 U/L), hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia
